Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), governed by the differential equations \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\), where A and B are constant matrices. The system undergoes a Fourier transformation \\( F(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-i\\omega t}z(t) dt \\), which modifies its spectral components.

Given \\( F(z) \\) at a frequency \\( \\omega \\), is it possible to exactly recover \\( z(0) \\), the original state at t = 0, without any additional information?
Explanation: While the inverse Fourier transform can theoretically recover \\( z(t) \\) from \\( F(z) \\), perfect reconstruction of \\( z(0) \\) from a single frequency component \\( \\omega \\) is not feasible without the complete spectrum. Individual frequency components do not contain all necessary information due to the frequency-domain transformation.
